comments.text:
I know this is an old video, but I would just like to point out that the 
tweet is still up, with more than 23,000 retweets: 
https://twitter.com/rickygervais/status/336856739800571905
The first time he posted, it had a spelling mistake so he removed that 
tweet and tweeted again to fix it (see this reply: 
https://twitter.com/Kuma/status/336857918622273536)﻿
comments.author: Teresa Martins

comments.text:
How was this mocking Christians? It was mocking United States media's way 
of dealing with natural or man-made disasters. American media often just 
says "Eh, pray for 'em, don't bother with money or support".﻿
comments.author: F/R/E/A/K

comments.text:
That was really funny. Why would that be controversial? Saying your in my 
prayers is the polite religious way of saying I don't plan on helping.﻿
comments.author: Tim Leonard

comments.text:
Come on guys, I'm Christian and I thought it was funny. I believe in God 
and I believe in prayer, but sending money is useful when disasters happen. 
And it was a good joke, we need to lighten up a bit more as a group.﻿

comments.text:
wow this is a new low for Gervais. i shouldnt be surprised that he would 
take a natural disaster and make it all about HIM. This is just typical 
atheist behaviour though to be fair, most ahteists have the same agressive 
demeanor that compells them to go out and look for confrontatiomns and to 
challenge anyone who diosnt follow their beliefs and in this case he does 
just that, unnecessarily targeting celebrities for the way they offer help 
to people, its just rude and obnoxious of him, he just cant restrain 
himself and accept how others cope and process this stuff. i mean we get 
it, you are a non believer, but guess what, this isnt about you, or your 
opinions this is about victims of a tornado. targeting certain celebrities 
because they sent prayers to the victims and trying to one up them by 
saying how much money you sent, and how their methods of helping are wrong? 
thats low. ﻿

comments.text:
I know lots of christians. I know lots of atheists. I know agnostics, 
buddhists and jews. I don't know any hindu's or muslims, but I would like 
to. We've all got on well. We all have our qualities and we all have our 
flaws. The inescapable conclusion I have arrived at is that our religious 
views, or lack thereof, have nothing to do with who we are as people. The 
point I'm trying to make is, I don't dislike you because you have a 
different opinion to me. I dislike you because you're an asshole.

comments.text:
